Baby Monster Blues
Monster Rancher Metropolis: Monster Rancher Advance 2 Archive (GameBoy Advance): Miscellaneous Q&A (Post New Questions Here): Baby Monster Blues
By GoldenBoy on Sunday, December 8, 2002 - 09:42 am:

Everyone has had a baby that is difficult in the
early part of his life. Well one way to avoid
trouble and get to bigger statgains sooner is to
raise Reliance(Loyalty) With 2nd gen monsters
this isn't hard they can be born with up to 40
Reliance already.

But I've found one good way to get a baby going
on the right track is lots of gifts.
There are two categories of items, Snacks and
Presents. Snacks are limited to one a week as the
monster gets "full" but you can give several
presents in the same week.

So when you bring a baby home, try this: find a
gift item that Holly says he likes (monster toys
or flowers are availabe in the shop, I haven't
checked the others yet to see what categories
they are) I tested a baby Manirin and got his
reliance up to 7 in week 1 with 2 Flowers and a
MonToy. His raising style was still at normal
too, I will be checking to see how much it takes
to head toward spoiled.

More research is to follow, I just wanted to give
you guys a heads up.

By nowd on Sunday, December 8, 2002 - 06:11 pm:

Here's my "Baby Monster Blues", the GLUTTON char! So far, ALL the monsters I've raised o far eventually get this char. Can anyone tell me how to avoid this? I usually feed my monster a "balanced" diet of meat, fish and fruits (orange or banana). Also, what exactly does Glutton do to your monster?

In line with this, does milk still work? I mean, it's really just a force of habit that I carry with me from the older games. But is it still adviseable to feed your monster milk for the first few months of its life even if it doesn't make it happy? Just curious :P

By GoldenBoy on Sunday, December 8, 2002 - 07:23 pm:

Most baby monsters get Glutton and then will lose
it when they reach adulthood. Its one of the ways
the game governs you from working the baby
monster too hard. Don't worry about it too much.

I get rid of it whenever I get the adult warning,
by feeding vitamins for a month or two. I may use
diet weed if the monster has gone to fat instead
of just obese. Surgery is pointless (ask Lisa)
the trait will more than likely come back the
next week.

By Lisa Shock on Sunday, December 8, 2002 - 08:35 pm:

Yeah, I removed Glutton and it came right back: a complete waste of 1,000g!

By Reaper on Wednesday, December 11, 2002 - 07:31 am:

Is it bad to be strict on your monster
the first one i raised was spoilt
the next one said strict
and now they all say stricter

i just need to know how this effects my monsters

By GoldenBoy on Wednesday, December 11, 2002 - 07:37 am:

This has been pretty constant through all MR
games, the more strict you are the bigger
statgains you get, but the shorter the monster's
life due to stress. There are some stages where
being a little strict is actually good. I try to
be strict early on then ease off as the monster
gets older.

By Joey on Wednesday, December 11, 2002 - 10:42 am:

Check your monster's stat every week. When it becomes "spoilt", just give it something it doesn't like. Most monsters don't like wine and charred newt. Alternatively, if you don't want to spend money (cheapskate!), just enter a battle, win it, and don't praise your monster. These two methods are guaranteed to bring back the status to "pampered".

By Zelandonii Rancher on Wednesday, December 11, 2002 - 03:06 pm:

You think thats bad? I am obviously not the best at this game, but I completely mucked up when I removed Glutton 5 times in a row from my monster then just gave up...I can't believe I did that now...I feel stupid...but, from what I can see, it does nothing, you can still only give it one food item a week and it gets the same nutrients from each item, so I have no idea about it...oh well.

By GoldenBoy on Wednesday, December 11, 2002 - 05:05 pm:

all glutton is for is to moderate how much work
you can do to a young or spoiled monster. it
seems to increase the amount of tiredness a
monster gets when doing a drill. The only upside
to it is it may also buffer stress. I have a hard
time stressing out baby monsters, although that
might be because of items.

By Divine Dragoon on Monday, December 16, 2002 - 01:23 pm:

different from your experience.

By TrailBlazer on Wednesday, December 18, 2002 - 06:07 am:

er... i have a question.. why is spoiling the monster bad? does it reduce lifespan?

By GoldenBoy on Wednesday, December 18, 2002 - 07:06 am:

It may actually increase lifespan, but like Holly
says, the monster won't take his training
seriously. Which means lower gains, more
failures, and willful behavior.

By GoldenBoy on Thursday, January 30, 2003 - 03:15 pm:

So far its impossible to tell if its better or worse. It seems better, just like it did the first time I had a 6trait baby, but I will have to play out his life to know for sure.

My theory is, best lifespans come from being able to keep Glutton until its almost ready to go on its own. My two best lived monsters both had glutton until right around the adult warning (a little longer) and it seemed to help. Again its speculation, I have nothing to back it up, ymmv.

By Genki on Friday, February 21, 2003 - 06:58 pm:

Whenever I get a new monster, I either get Glutton or not depending on what's the first food I feed them...

If I give them food that makes it so that their figure is Obese, or Fat, like Meat or Fish, I get Glutton.

If I give them food that makes it so that their figure is Thin, or Normal, like Vitamins or Nuts, I either don't get glutton or lose glutton.

From my experiences I would think that Glutton is actually a predictable trait, maybe in a ways like Popular.

By Ken Kaji on Thursday, March 27, 2003 - 09:25 pm:

from my experiance glutton is controllable.
truths as far as me (i dont no about u, though):
1)Removing glutton with surgery while monster is fat or obese is useless.
2)The more a monster likes a food, the more they'll eat it, thus increasing possibility of weight gain.
3) foods that are more filling, like meat and fish, contribute more to weight gain, while emptier foods, like vitamins and desert, contirbute less, and can possible slim the monster.
4) "Nothing" is a good way to slim your monster fast if you dont mind the stress and losing 2-3 points of reliance.
5) i'v had times when the monster was fat, but no glutton since i fed it nothing that month, gave it one dietweed, and POW! it had glutton.
6) after the first time, which i have a pain trying to avoid, glutton is easily prevented by feeding foods moderatly liked and moderatly filling or, if this isn't possible, like with my Chaos head that likes fish and meat and hates everything else, switching between the semi extremes, i.e. meat, 3 points satisfied, not happy/worry holly, one month, then potatoes, 1 point filled but not harsh, the next or meat, 1 point, then dessert, 4 points. these are not exact plans but just the general concept of my monster normal diet.after that first 3 month or so period of obesity, (yes i get rid of it that soon, i hate glutton!) my monster stays normal with my diet, except towards the end when they get all anorexic and turn thin, but i'm afraid to spoil them.
7) When fed cheese, some monsters get fat exactly the way a rock wouldn't.

By Jimeous on Thursday, August 7, 2003 - 10:38 am:

Training and Resting increase a monsters weight, obviously "food" does the same.

Sparring and Battles decrease weight. You'll find that by the time your monster reaches "adulthood" you'll be entering more tournaments.

In essence, the more you battle the more weight your monster loses. So what seems like the Glutton trait not appearing is actually you battling more.

The worst affect of Glutton is it maintains the Obese figure. This greatly affects training because you will need more rest or stress/fatigue supplements so you can do more training. And as resting and training only increase your weight you're back to where you started. :p

My unfounded theory for getting Glutton is because your monster is at the farm training and resting, most likely why it "finds" items, its got a food stash somehere we don't know about....

LoL
